name: Tyrosine
summary: L-Tyrosine is an amino acid precursor to dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine, studied for its potential to support cognitive function, stress resilience, and mood under demanding conditions.
description: Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid found in protein-rich foods and synthesized in the body from phenylalanine. It serves as a precursor for catecholamine neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine) and thyroid hormones. Supplementation has been investigated for enhancing cognitive performance under stress, fatigue, and sleep deprivation, as well as for supporting mood and motivation. While it may help preserve mental performance in stressful situations, evidence for benefits in depression or ADHD is mixed.

metadata.natural_source: Protein-rich foods (dairy, soy, meats, fish, eggs)

primary_indications: Support for cognitive performance under stress, fatigue, or sleep deprivation
contraindications: Hyperthyroidism (tyrosine is a thyroid hormone precursor)

items: Helps maintain cognitive performance during acute stress or sleep deprivation
Provides precursor support for catecholamine neurotransmitters
Used by some as an adjunct in mood or attention-related conditions

sections.text: L-Tyrosine is converted into L-DOPA by tyrosine hydroxylase, the rate-limiting enzyme in catecholamine synthesis. L-DOPA is then converted into dopamine, which can further convert into norepinephrine and epinephrine. Tyrosine also contributes to thyroid hormone synthesis. Supplementation may help replenish catecholamine levels under conditions of high demand (stress, fatigue, cold exposure, or sleep deprivation).

adult.typical: 500–2,000 mg taken 30–60 minutes before stress exposure, demanding tasks, or workouts.
adult.note: N-Acetyl-L-Tyrosine (NALT) is sometimes marketed as more bioavailable, though evidence is limited.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended; safety not well established.

sections.text: Effects on alertness and cognition may be noticed within 1–2 hours; duration of benefit typically a few hours.

serious: Hypertension or anxiety (rare, with high doses or in sensitive individuals)

other: May overstimulate in combination with other stimulants or high caffeine intake.
Avoid excessive chronic use without medical supervision.

items.action: Avoid combination or separate by several hours

items: Monitor thyroid status in at-risk individuals
Watch for mood or sleep disturbances
Blood pressure if used with stimulants

sections.pregnancy: Insufficient safety data; avoid unless medically supervised
sections.pediatrics: Not well studied; avoid outside medical supervision
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe, monitor for blood pressure and thyroid function

sections.text: No tapering required; can be discontinued without withdrawal effects.

items: Most beneficial under conditions of stress, fatigue, or sleep deprivation rather than for routine use.
NALT form has limited evidence supporting improved absorption compared to L-Tyrosine.
Effectiveness in depression and ADHD remains inconclusive.

items.label: Deijen JB, et al. Tyrosine supplementation and cognitive performance. Brain Res Bull. 1999
Hase A, et al. Effects of tyrosine on cognitive performance and stress. Nutrients. 2015

seo.title: Tyrosine – Stress Resilience & Cognitive Support
seo.description: L-Tyrosine is an amino acid precursor to dopamine and norepinephrine, studied for stress resilience, mood, and cognitive performance under demanding conditions.
